User-Agent:       Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; rv:2.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/4.0
Build Identifier: 6.1.7601

With some fonts (tested Cambria, Droid Serif, Georgia and Liberation Serif) greek capital letters which have a smooth breathing mark (so called psili; http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Smooth_breathing) the diacritical mark is displayed on the right side of the letter instead of the left side.
However, this effects only some fonts. With the above mentioned ones I can reproduce the bug. With Times New Roman and Linux Libertine the letters are rendered correct.

View this sample page http://isaac.aquilatech.org/onlinebibel/markuptest/interlinear_test.html with different browsers. I tested it with Firefox 4, Opera 10, Chrome 11, Safari 5 and Internet Explorer 9. Firefox is the onl one who fails in this task.

Reproducible: Always

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open http://isaac.aquilatech.org/onlinebibel/markuptest/interlinear_test.html
2. Look at the greek capital letters with the psili (last line)
Actual Results:  
The diacritical mark is rendered on the right side of the capital letter.

Expected Results:  
The diacritical mark should have been rendered on the left side of the capital letter.

comments.text: Could you please provide a screenshot to show the rendering you get? My current guess is that the "problem" fonts do not actually support the characters concerned, so you're getting fallback to a different font where the diacritic is placed to the right side. If we can confirm what's happening, perhaps we can adjust the font-matching behavior to prefer a better font for this range.

comments.text:
I did some further testing. As aravindm already said (Comment 1), the bug is introduced in Firefox 3.7 Alpha 4.

This bug is "dependent" on the operating system.

Here is my test list:

Windows 2000 SP4:
 - 3.6: works
 - 4.0: works

Windows XP SP3:
 - 3.6: works
 - 4.0: broken

Windows Vista SP2:
 - 3.6: works
 - 4.0: works

Windows 7 SP1:
 - 3.6: works
 - 4.0: broken

(All 32-bit systems. Windows 2000 and XP only tested in a virtual environment but this shouldn't affect the behaviour.)

This is very strange.... I see the same "incorrect" rendering using the Cambria font in Notepad on Win7; I also see it in a simple test in Chrome 10, but not in the example page mentioned here.

Given that I'm seeing the same problem in Notepad, I think this may be a Windows font-rendering bug rather than a Firefox bug, but I don't understand exactly what's causing it or why some programs/examples show the problem and others don't.

Yeah you're right. This get's stranger and stranger... I can confirm the same bug in Notepad on Windows 7.

Did some further testing with the font "Cambria Math". This one behaves even stranger. The capital letters provided in the sample page (Ἀ Ἐ Ἠ Ἰ Ὀ Ὠ) don't display the diacritic at all if the letters stand for themself. However when they have a preceding character (but not a space) they show the diacritic on the right side (left). (The Consolas font seems to have the same bug as I see typing this message.)

Given all this I think this is still partly a Firefox bug since the rendering behaviour changes between 3.7a3 and 3.7a4.

Weird.
